attributes.title: Building Capacity To Evaluate the Community Collaborations to Strengthen and Preserve Families (CWCC) Cross-Site Process Evaluation

q1.value: Building Capacity to Evaluate Child Welfare Community Collaborations to Strengthen and Preserve Families (CWCC) Cross-Site Process Evaluation

q2.value: Carolyn Jean Layzer, Jessica Walker, Allison Hyra, Karin Malm

q3.value:
The study is a cross-site process evaluation to describe how 13 communities across the United States implemented the Community Collaborations to Strengthen and Preserve Families grants awarded in fiscal years 2018 and 2019 (FY18-FY19) by the Children's Bureau within the Administration for Children and Families, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. A major aim of the Building Capacity to Evaluate Child Welfare Community Collaborations to Strengthen and Preserve Families (CWCC) Cross-Site Process Evaluation is to advance understanding of collaborative approaches to preventing child maltreatment. 

The study will employ a mixed methods design and collect data between spring 2020 through summer of 2024. It will address the following research questions:

1. What are the promising approaches and challenges in identifying, establishing, and maintaining new and existing partnerships?

2. How are data being linked and used within and across agencies to: (1) identify families in need of child abuse and neglect (CAN) prevention services; (2) identify the specific needs of families; (3) make informed decisions about service provision; (4) inform continuous quality improvement; and (5) track outcomes?

3. How are grant implementation activities structured and operationalized, within and across CWCC grantees?

4. What factors—including state and local policies, geographical location (rural vs. urban), resources, staff and organizational capacity, training, cross-partnership coordination, and existing infrastructure—promote or impede implementation of the child welfare community collaborations, within and across CWCC grantees?

5. To what extent are CWCC grantees planning to sustain activities beyond the current grant, and what factors do they believe will help or hinder these efforts? 

The study is being conducted by an independent third-party evaluator, Abt Associates and their partners Child Trends and Dr. Sharon McGroder, under contract with the Office of Planning, Research, and Evaluation within the Administration for Children and Families, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.

q4.value: N/A. This is an exploratory study.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This study uses observational and descriptive methods to address the following research questions:

1. What are the promising approaches and challenges in identifying, establishing, and maintaining new and existing partnerships?

2. How are data being linked and used within and across agencies to: (1) identify families in need of child abuse and neglect (CAN) prevention services; (2) identify the specific needs of families; (3) make informed decisions about service provision; (4) inform continuous quality improvement; and (5) track outcomes?

3. How are grant implementation activities structured and operationalized, within and across CWCC grantees?

4. What factors—including state and local policies, geographical location (rural vs. urban), resources, staff and organizational capacity, training, cross-partnership coordination, and existing infrastructure—promote or impede implementation of the child welfare community collaborations, within and across CWCC grantees?

5. To what extent are CWCC grantees planning to sustain activities beyond the current grant, and what factors do they believe will help or hinder these efforts?

Methods of primary data collection include 4 years of annual efforts to collection information via: surveys of all grant program staff to capture their experiences in collaboration activities, observations of collaboration activities, and interviews with key program staff, leadership, and community leaders affiliated with each of the 13 CWCC grant projects. The study will also collect secondary data ("program documents") of grantee-produced reports and deliverables, such as grant-mandated semi-annual progress reports and staff training manuals.   

Qualitative data will be analyzed using a grounded theory approach that includes content analysis and consensus coding to identify and summarize themes, patterns, key activities, and practices related to implementing and sustaining the CWCC grantees' projects. Quantitative data from surveys will be analyzed using descriptive methods, including calculation of frequencies, ranges, means, and standard deviations. 

Please note: this study is part of a larger contract. The contract also provides evaluation technical assistance to the local evaluators associated with each of the 13 CWCC grantees. We are supporting their efforts to design and implement local high quality process and outcome evaluations. How grantees implement their evaluation is outside of this process study.

q9.value: N/A. Randomization will not be employed.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: The study will also collect program documents that include grantee-produced reports and deliverables, such as grant-mandated implementation plans, semi-annual progress reports, and staff training manuals. Some of the 13 grantees have already provided such materials.

question.value:
Primary Data Collection: The process study team will conduct in-person interviews and observations with key program staff and leadership affiliated with the CWCC grantee and its partners. Data in the form of notes and transcripts will be collected during four site visits to each of the 13 CWCC grantees. The subjects of the interviews and observations will be identified based on their roles and experience on the project and recruited by the grantee's project director in coordination with the process study team. 

In addition, the process study team will field an online collaboration survey among all project staff affiliated with CWCC grant activities (at the grantee and its partners). The collaboration survey will be collected on an annual basis for four years. The collaboration survey sample will be identified by each grantees’ project director and is intended to be inclusive of all individuals who have a role in the CWCC grant. Grantees' project directors will provide the contact information for the identified sample. The study team will reach out directly to each sample member to invite them to voluntarily complete the survey, providing a URL with which to access the online collaboration survey. 

Secondary Data Collection: CWCC grantees will be asked to share with the process study team copies of project-produced reports and deliverables, such as grant-mandated semi-annual progress reports and staff training manuals. We will collect these on a semi-annual basis via email or during site visits.

q13.value:
We will survey the populations in the universe of 13 CWCC grantees (four FY18 grantees and nine FY19 grantees) and the individuals who contribute to their grant. We describe the samples for each data collection below. 

Collaboration Survey: We estimate the population of individuals (project staff) associated with the implementation of the 13 CWCC grants to be around 845 individuals (65 individuals per grant, 13 total grantees). The survey will be administered to the entire population. 

Interviews: To form a sample from this population for interviews, the process study team will ask each CWCC grantees’ project director to provide the names and contact information of individuals involved in grant activity execution and leadership. This is expected to be a census of all individuals with a role on the grant, but we cannot independently confirm what percent of total project staff the grantee provides contact information for, or the representativeness of, that sample. However, we anticipate high levels of participation in interviews and will strive for diversity in roles and experiences among the interviewees. The sample for interviews will be composed of one project director from each of the 13 CWCC grantees and four leaders of partner organizations from each grantee (n = 65 project directors/leaders), as well as 18 frontline staff from each of the 13 CWCC grantees and their partner organizations (n = 234 frontline staff). The project will interview the same grant leader each of our four visits, and will interview two different sets of partner leaders and staff. One set of partner leaders and staff will be interviewed during our first round of site visits. That same set of individuals will be interviewed again during our third round of site visits. We will schedule interviews with a different set of partner leaders and staff during our second round of site visits and re-interview them on our fourth round. 

Program Documents: All 13 CWCC grantees and their partners will share key program documents with the process study team on an annual basis, as part of site visits.

Observations: All 13 CWCC grantees will be asked to provide the process study team an opportunity to observe a grant-related activity during site visits.

q14.value:
Collaboration Survey: The sample size is based on the total population of individuals associated with the implementation of the 13 CWCC grants. We intend to include as much of the population as is referred for and voluntarily participates in data collection for the study.

Interviews: The sample size is based on the number of individuals the process study team can feasibly interview in the span of a three- to four-day site visit.

Program Documents: The sample size is based on the universe of 13 FY18-FY19 CWCC grantees and the number of documents that they create. 

Observations: The sample size is based on the universe of 13 FY18-FY19 CWCC grantees.

q15.value:
Data collection is limited to the sample size for which we have Paperwork Reduction Act clearance from the Federal Office of Management and Budget (OMB). 

     - For interviews, the maximum sample size is 65 project directors/leaders and 234 
       frontline staff across the 13 CWCC grantees their partner organizations. 

     - For the collaboration survey, the maximum sample size is 845 staff across the 13 CWCC 
       grantees their partner organizations.  

We think it likely that the interview and survey samples will include as many individuals as are referred by the 13 CWCC grantees and agree to participate in data collection. 

For observations, the sample size is 13 grantees, equal to the total population of CWCC grantees that exists. Each grantee will be observed four times, for a total of 52 observations. 

For program documents, the sample size is 13 grantees, equal to the total population of CWCC grantees that exists. Each grantee will provide an unlimited number of documents for review based on the number of documents that they create.

question.value: No manipulated variables.

Using data from the collaboration survey, we will generate an average score for each grantee on each of seven collaboration factors: context, members, process, communication, function, resources, and leadership. The steps we will take to do this are: (1) add together all the ratings for the questions or statements related to each factor; and (2) divide by the total number of ratings for those questions (this number is equal to the number of raters multiplied by the number of questions for the factor). We will use the same approach for the perceptions of success scales. Depending on sample size within each grantee (e.g., each cell must have an N of 6 or more), we may calculate average scores across the seven collaboration factors based on respondent background characteristics such as when the respondent became involved in the grant or whether respondents are managers/leaders or front line staff.

This is an exploratory study using qualitative and descriptive research methods. It does not involve hypothesis testing or statistical modeling. 

Qualitative Analysis: The qualitative analysis will consist of coding observation forms, interview transcripts, and program documents to identify themes, patterns, key activities, and practices using NVivo software. The process study team will have a pre-analysis meeting to discuss themes and patterns in the data and use those themes and patterns as the basis to develop a code book. Each document will be coded by two individuals, and a reconciler will resolve any discrepancies in coding. 

We will use the grounded theory approach to qualitative analysis, which entails a systematic approach to coding and thematic analysis to search for patterns, exemplary events, key activities, collaborative approaches, practices, goals, and processes recorded in notes from interviews and site visits. Patterns and themes are identified through a simultaneous process of deduction and induction involving the comparison of responses and grouping similar concepts together in categories (e.g., key successes and key challenges in implementation). As additional data are collected over time, initial categories will be elaborated further and augmented.

We will use content analysis to review the qualitative data collected for this evaluation to determine the presence of specific words or concepts. We will use those findings to enumerate and categorize findings from the CWCC grantees’ program documents and from our interview and site visit observation notes. Our inductive methods will allow us to describe the activities and implementation of each CWCC grantee, and to make descriptive comparisons across the sites. We will also be able to identify common and unique implementation challenges and lessons learned by CWCC grantees from program documents, site visit observations, and interviews. 

Consensus coding will be used to yield common themes and threads related to the perceptions and experiences of staff from partner organizations/agencies involved in the implementation of the CWCC initiative. The process study team will hold analytic meetings throughout the coding process to review the data, discuss emerging themes, agree upon coding strategies, and update the codebook. 

The qualitative analyses from the collaboration survey will result in summaries by individual CWCC grantee and across all 13 CWCC grantees that describe themes, patterns, key activities, and practices.

Descriptive Analysis: The descriptive analysis planned includes calculation of frequencies, ranges, means, and standard deviations for quantitative data collected in the collaboration survey. The collaboration survey will be fielded annually for four years. For each survey year, responses from the full survey sample (i.e., individuals involved in grant activity execution and leadership across all 13 CWCC grantees) will be pooled and analyzed together. Analysis will be conducted using Excel or SAS.

q20.value:
Qualitative Data: N/A

Quantitative Data: No transformations are planned.

q21.value: N/A. This is an exploratory study using qualitative and descriptive research methods.

q22.value:
Quantitative Data: Quantitative data from the collaboration survey will be cleaned and checked for quality prior to calculating frequencies, ranges, means, and standard deviations. We will not exclude any quantitative data except in circumstances where the validity or accuracy of data appears to be compromised. For example, if we encounter cases with evidence of straight-lining, which occurs when a survey participant chooses the same response option for each item in a survey, we may remove those cases. We do not anticipate many outliers on the collaboration survey because the majority of responses are bounded on 5-point and 10-point scales. There are only four survey items that include open fields. Should we find responses in these fields that are illogical, impossible, or uninterpretable (e.g., a report of having attended 200 collaboration meetings in the past two months), we may set those responses to missing.  

Qualitative Data: No data from interviews or observations will be excluded from the qualitative analysis.

q23.value:
When calculating frequencies, ranges, means, and standard deviations, we will analyze all available cases. Cases with missing data with be deleted in a list-wise fashion. 

Likewise, the qualitative analysis will include all available data.

q24.value: This exploratory process study does not involve hypothesis testing and primarily qualitative in nature. Therefore an analytic model is not pre-specified, and no confirmatory or exploratory analyses are specified.

q25.value: In addition to conducting this study, Abt Associates and its partners, Child Trends and Dr. Sharon McGroder, provide evaluation technical assistance to the CWCC grantees and their local evaluators to support them in conducting their own process and outcomes evaluations. Most members of the process study team do not provide evaluation technical assistance. Given the independence of both the process study team and the technical assistance team from programmatic operations, we do not consider this to pose any conflict of interest or threaten our independence as evaluators.

attributes.title: Scoping review protocol on protective factors that promote LGBTI+ youth wellbeing
attributes.description: Online supplementary data to ensure Data Availability for submission of scoping review protocol to HRB Open

comments.value:
This pre-registration of online supplementary material in relation to the submission of a  scoping review protocol to HRB Open Research. To date:
1. A preliminary search of scoping, systematic or any other type of review was conducted across the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Campbell Collection, Epistemonikos, JBI Evidence Synthesis, Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects and PROSPERO. 
2. An initial keyword search was piloted across three electronic databases: PubMed, PsycINFO and ASSIA. 
3. Informal consultation was undertaken with key stakeholders, including LGBTI+ young people. 
4. The study team further revised and refined the search strategy in consultation with a university social science subject librarian.
5. The approach outlined above has informed the final search strategy keyword terms, index headings, ti/abs/key search criteria and databases for inclusion

attributes.title: Teaching, Autism and the Cognitive Foundations of Human Culture

q1.value: Do ASD and TD children differ in teaching approach to children of different ages?

q3.value: Children with autism experience difficulty with tracking the mental states of others, i.e. Theory of Mind (ToM). ToM is often assumed to be a fundamental pre-requisite for human teaching (see refs in other section, 1-3), but evidence is lacking. To investigate the role of ToM in teaching, we will perform an experiment to test whether children with Autism and typically developing children differ in their ability to teach.

q4.value:
ToM is often assumed to be necessary for teaching, but in principle physical and behavioural cues from pupils may allow teachers to target their teaching appropriately without the need to infer mental states. We therefore hypothesise that participants with autism will be able to adjust teaching to their pupils depending on observable cues. In this experiment we will test whether typically developing (TD) and cognitively-matched autistic (ASD) “teachers” take different teaching approaches depending on the age of naïve pupils.

Participants will be asked to create two separate teaching videos for two different pupils, varying by age. These videos will be measured on a variety of dimensions which capture key aspects of the verbal content, and acoustic properties of the teacher’s instructions. Further details on the relevance of these variables, the precise definitions and the methods used to capture them, are detailed in the variables section of this document.

Predictions:

In comparison with teaching older pupils, both TD and ASD teachers will; 
•	Give a greater number of instructions to younger pupils. 
•	Deliver a greater proportion of specific instructions to younger pupils. 
•	Deliver a greater proportion of process instructions to younger pupils. 
•	Use fewer words with younger pupils. 
•	Use a higher mean fundamental frequency (i.e. the base pitch of vocalisations) per- 
        utterance, with younger pupils. 
•	Use fewer words-per-minute with younger pupils.
•	Use longer pauses between utterances with younger pupils.
•	Use shorter utterances with younger pupils.

question.value:
The experiment will consist of two sessions. The first session will be for screening and preparation. If the participant meets criteria, they will be invited back to a second session, where the experiment itself will be administered. In the experiment, participants will involve creating instructional videos for pupils of different ages (5 year old pupil and a 10 year old pupil), on the subject of how to build a Lego catapult. These sessions will be no more than one week apart.

Screening:

Screening will consist of psychological testing, and some time spent on independently learning how to build the Lego catapult. The screening measures consist of:
- Social and Communication Questionnaire (SCQ) lifetime version.
- Wechsler Abbreviated Scale of Intelligence (WASI) Vocabulary and Block design tasks.
- ToM Triangles Animation task.

SCQ (ref 4):
Prior to screening parents will be asked to complete the Social and Communication Questionnaire (SCQ), two 40-item, binary choice questionnaires that query sociality, communication and range of interests. One questionnaire probes for a picture of how the child is doing currently, and the other for a picture of their development (lifetime). Lifetime scores above 15 indicate likely ASD. Only the lifetime version of the questionnaire will be administered. Children with lifetime scores above 15 will be included in the ASD group, but excluded if recruiting to the TD group. 

Questionnaires will be provided to parents of participating children before the first session (either sent in post or digitally via email), or if not possible they will be asked to complete the questionnaire during the screening session.

WASI Vocabulary and Block Design tasks (ref 5):
In order to assess verbal and motor skills, and to obtain a measure of general cognition (as expressed in predicted IQ), the WASI vocabulary and block design tasks will be administered as per the formal instructions. Participants in both groups that have a predicted IQ greater than or equal to 90 will be included. Additionally, participants in both groups that have a scaled score of greater than or equal to 8 for both the vocabulary and block design tasks will be included.

The second version (WASI-II) will be used. The WASI will be the first task administered in the screening session.

ToM Triangles Animation task (ref 6):
To assess degree of theory of mind, the participant will be presented with the triangles animation task. The participant is asked to give their qualitative understanding of a series of four scenarios depicted by abstract shapes. Participants are scored based on their descriptions of the animation's content and the behaviour of the triangle. For each scenario the participant is asked “what is happening in this animation?” Responses to each scenario are graded between 0 and 2 on two dimensions: Accuracy (i.e. the description of the content of the video) and Mentalisation (i.e. the language used to describe the interpreted thoughts and feelings of the triangles).

Independent learning of the Lego catapult:
Following completion of the screening tasks, the participant will learn how to build a Lego catapult. This will be done independently, so as to avoid any modelling of teaching on the part of the researcher. Participants will initially be given a simple Lego building task as a warm-up exercise, while the researcher organises and sets up for building the catapult. Once ready, the participant will be introduced to the catapult. They will be instructed by a building manual (see attached document), which details using pictures how to assemble the catapult. Additionally, the participant will be provided with a pre-built model of the catapult, which they may inspect but not amend in any way. The researcher will not be able to assist with the building of the catapult in any way, and will absent themselves from the table while the participant is learning to build the catapult. Once the participant confirms they understand the task, the researcher will leave the table and allow the participant to build the catapult independently. The participant will alert the researcher once they have finished building. If there are significant errors with the built catapult, the researcher will ask if the participant would like some more time to practice building it. Once the participant has demonstrated they understand how to build the catapult correctly, the session will end. If the participant is unable to build the catapult without significant errors, they will be not be included in the study.

Experiment Plan:

For the experiment, a mixed (within and between) design will be used. Two groups of participants will be recruited, ASD and typically developing adolescents (11 to 15 year olds). Participation will involve creating instructional videos for pupils of different ages (5 year old pupil and a 10 year old pupil). Each participant will create two instructional videos, aimed at different pupils. The order in which participants will create videos for their pupils will be counterbalanced, where an equal number of participants (within each group) will create the 5 year old video first to those who create the 10 year old video first. Participants will be introduced to their targeted pupil by way of a short video vignette (administered prior to the creation of the participant's instructional video), where the pupil states their name and age. The gender of the pupil will depend on the gender of the participants (to avoid any gender-related biases affecting teaching approach). The participants will not know how the pupils differ until they are introduced to the second pupil. During the video making process, the research will make themselves absent to avoid observational effects. The participant will be told they will have 10 minutes to make their video (however they will be allowed a maximum of 5 minutes of extra time if they require it), and that they should alert the researcher when they are finished. 

The general order of events during the experimental session are as follows:

- Introduction to the task.
- Participant re-familiarises themselves with how to build the catapult.
- Once participant is ready, they are introduced to their first pupil, via vignette.
- The participant is instructed on the video making process.
- The participant makes the video for the first pupil.
- The participant indicates they are finished.
- The Lego catapult is reset.
- The researcher introduces the participant to the second pupil, via vignette.
- The participant is reminded of the video making process.
- The participant makes the video for the second pupil.
- The participant indicates they are finished.
- The participant gives feedback and the researcher delivers the incentive.

A full experiment script is available as an attachment to this question.

Teaching approaches will be compared across both videos (on a number of variables which will be described later), between the ASD and typically developing groups.

q9.value:
There is a randomisation element to this study. To avoid effects of the pupil, the participants will be introduced to one of three random pupils for each condition (apart from in one condition where only two pupils were recorded - details later). As the gender of the presented pupil will depend on the gender of the participant, this means there are four potential conditions: 5 year old boy, 5 year old girl, 10 year old boy and 10 year old girl. Three vignettes have been recorded for each of these conditions, apart from in the 5 year old girl condition where only two were recorded. Additionally, the order of pupil age will be counterbalanced.

This means there are a total of 18 possible pupil pairings for male participants, and 12 possible pupil pairings for female participants.

For the purposes of counterbalancing, each participant will be assigned a pupil pairing from either the young pupil first or old pupil first blocks, split equally within participant groups (i.e. ASD and TD groups), so there are nine possible pupil pairings for each participant at time of allocation. Additionally, the researcher will use the same pupil pairings within each participant group.

As the sampling plan is to recruit a total sample size of 30, and ASD is disproportionately diagnosed in males, it is anticipated that not all the pupil pairings will be used.

question.value:
Adolescent children (11 to 15 year olds), who will act as "teachers" in the experiment, will be recruited via a variety of bodies (e.g. schools, council services, local clubs and organisations etc.). To recruit children with diagnoses of ASD, special education need coordinators will be approached in various schools in the south-west of England. When recruiting via schools, the parents/carers of prospective participants will be approached by a representative of the school to seek verbal permission for the researcher to get in touch with them, or to discuss their child's participation on the parent's behalf.

When the researcher is alerted to a prospective participant, they will discuss the suitability of the child for participation, with the appropriate adult (i.e. school representative or parent/carer). This conversation will involve checking the child's age, diagnoses, and whether they are performing at age-related targets for their verbal skills. If the child appears suitable for participation, then written consent will be sought from the parent and a date booked in for data collection to occur. As detailed in the design plan, at this point participants will undergo a more formal screening for general cognition. Any participants not meeting these criteria will be excluded from the analysis.

Participating children will be rewarded for their participation in the form of a Lego mini-figure (approximately worth £1.50 each). Parents of participating children will not be materially incentivised.

Recruitment will occur from the present (March 2020) until an appropriate sample size has been recruited. This is anticipated to be completed before the end of this academic year (July 2020).

question.value:
There are two manipulated variables:
- Participant group (ASD or TD).
- Pupil age (5 year or 10 year).

Where all participants are either in the ASD or TD group, and all participants complete both pupil age conditions.

Details for how pupil age is manipulated can be found in the design plan.

A number of variables will be measured in the screening and experimental phases of the study. The screening tools and the measurements drawn from these are detailed in the design plan. Here I will list the measures that will be recorded from the screening tools.

•	Participant Age
•	SCQ - Lifetime score.
•	WASI - Full Scale IQ (2 item)
•	WASI - Block Design Scaled Score
•	WASI - Vocabulary Scaled Score
•	ToM Triangles Animation - Accuracy Total Score
•	ToM Triangles Animation - Mentalisation Total Score

A new coding scheme based on available research has been devised to isolate components of teaching behaviours. These cover two modalities, verbal and audible.
•	Verbal = How language is used to convey instruction.
•	Acoustic = Properties of sound in the language used.

Verbal - Transcripts of the videos will be coded to identify each instructive step conveyed by the teacher. Each of these steps will be assigned two qualities: whether they are pupil-specific or generic; and whether the instruction is process focused or product focused. 

Specific vs generic was used as a contrast in Ashley and Tomasello (1998), in their comparison of 2.5, 3 and 3.5 year olds on a co-operative teaching task. In this experiment, a number of instructional qualities were considered however of key significance was the emergence of specific directive instructions in the older 3.5 year old group. 

Process vs product is a construct which distinguishes imitation from emulation. One of the major theories of cumulative cultural evolution posits that humans are process focused when they teach, we pass on the steps involved in teaching rather than conveying the final outcome. ToM is argued to be key to our ability to engage in process focused teaching.

I will treat both of these constructs as proportional variables, i.e. the amount of specific/generalised and process/product will be expressed as a % of the total instructions. Therefore only two variables will be necessary to capture this distinction, one variable for the proportion of specific instruction and one variable for the proportion of process instruction.

Examples of how transcripts will be coded, will follow:
•	“So now you make the handle”
o	This example is pupil specific because it directly addresses the pupil.
o	It is also product focused because it only describes the end state, not the process.
•	“The tower goes here, on the base of the catapult”
o	This example is generic, it does not directly address the pupil.
o	It is also a process focused instruction, because it describes how to perform the task.

Due to the nature of creating an instructional video teachers may use visual gestures to supplement their instruction giving. Coding will account for any visual aids used in the instruction giving process. Unless the teacher clearly demonstrates the process to the camera, the instruction will only be coded as product focused. For example:
•	“To make the head of the catapult, you put it together like this [Head is shown to screen]”
o	This would be pupil specific.
o	This would be process focused. Although the process is not described verbally, it is conveyed visually.

Additionally, we will capture how much instruction is given to different pupils through examination of the transcripts. Although we have not yet seen any teaching research explore this, it seems intuitively worth exploring. This will be captured in two ways:
•	Instructional count (i.e. the number of verbal instructions given to each pupil).
•	Words-per-minute (i.e. how many words are used from the time between the start of talking to the finish).

Acoustic – IDS is characterised by a number of augmentations to speech. In this experiment I do not have the means to measure all of these, however a number of bodies of work point to some augmentations which may be possible to be isolated. 

One of these is fundamental frequency (F0), the base pitch of our voice which is modulated to higher frequency bands when speaking to infants. In order to isolate and examine F0 differences across groups and pupil types, the researcher will follow the data scoring approach outlined in Braarud & Stormark (2008). In this study, the researchers cleaned the audio of background noise, then isolated each word or sound uttered by their participants as a ‘vocal unit’. Each of these vocal units was then subjected to pitch extraction to give an F0 for each 3.6ms of voice production. Mean F0 will be taken across vocal units produced for each participant and each video made.

Additionally we will investigate pause and utterance durations, in line with research from Fernald & Simon (1984). In this study, utterances were defined as any section of speech bounded by pauses of longer than 300ms. Pitch extraction, pause and utterance analysis will be performed in PRAAT.

Summary:
To summarise I have SEVEN dependent variables, which I will compare across groups and pupil types. These are: proportion of specific instructions, (relative to generic instructions), proportion of process instructions (relative to product instructions), counts of numbers of instructions given, words-per-minute, fundamental frequency (F0), mean pause duration and mean utterance duration.
A principal components analysis will be conducted on the nine dependent measures. The exact method is described in the analysis plan section.

Prior to analysis of the data, groups will be compared to ensure they meet certain assumptions for the rationale. Groups will be contrasted on measures of motor-coordination (i.e. WASI block design), verbal skills (i.e. WASI vocabulary), general cognitive ability (i.e. predicted full scale IQ as compiled by a composite of block design and vocabulary performance) and theory of mind (i.e. triangles animation task). A one way ANOVA will be run on these measures, with group being a fixed factor. The control and ASD group will be assumed to match on motor co-ordination, verbal skills and general cognitive ability, but not match on the measure of theory of mind. If the one way ANOVA supports these assumptions, then I will proceed with the full analysis of the teaching data.

I will analyse the teaching data using a generalised linear mixed model (GLMM), specifying participant group and pupil type as fixed effects. Teacher identity will be fitted as a random effect to account for repeated measures. The outcome measures that are used in the model will depend on the outcome of an initial principal components analysis (PCA).

Two PCAs will be run; one for the verbal measures and one for the acoustic measures. If the PCA outcome gives components with Eigenvalues greater than 1, that are correlated, the GLMM will be run on the components to assess for significance. This means that a minimum of two GLMMs will be run, with the potential for further GLMMs if a PCA returns more than one component eigenvalue greater than 1.

If the PCA does not return components with Eigenvalues greater than 1 and correlated, then two separate GLMMs (for verbal and acoustic measures) will be run on the constituent dependent measures.

All the response variables are continuous. Standard residual checks will be administered to ensure that model assumptions are met for each analysis. If the distribution of the data is not Gaussian then a link function will be used to ensure that this is accounted for.

q20.value: For GLMM analyses we will assess model fit using standard residual plot techniques, and transform data where necessary.

q21.value: We will conduct model selection using Akaike Information Criterion (AIC), adopting a nesting rule to avoid retaining unnecessarily complex models (ref 7).

q22.value:
Participants will be screened as part of recruitment, and any who do not meet the criteria set out will not be asked to make any videos (see design plan for details of these). Any videos that participants make which are excessively brief (i.e. videos made that are under 20 seconds in length) will not be included in the analysis. If videos this short are made, the researcher will encourage the participant to make a more detailed video.

We will use Cook's distances to assess outliers, and will adopt a transparent approach of reporting the results of analyses including and excluding outliers.

q23.value: Any participants who do not complete both videos (and therefore provide complete data), or if there are any technical issues with the footage, will be excluded from the study. New participants will be recruited to replace these cases.

Experiment Plan:

For the experiment, a mixed (within and between) design will be used. Two groups of participants will be recruited, ASD and typically developing adolescents (11 to 15 year olds). Participation will involve creating instructional videos for pupils of different ages (5 year old pupil and a 10 year old pupil). Each participant will create two instructional videos, aimed at different pupils. The order in which participants will create videos for their pupils will be counterbalanced, where an equal number of participants (within each group) will create the 5 year old video first to those who create the 10 year old video first. Participants will be introduced to their targeted pupil by way of a short video vignette (administered prior to the creation of the participant's instructional video), where the pupil states their name and age. The gender of the pupil will depend on the gender of the participants (to avoid any gender-related biases affecting teaching approach). The participants will not know how the pupils differ until they are introduced to the second pupil. During the video making process, the research will make themselves absent to avoid observational effects. The participant will be told they will have 10 minutes to make their video (however they will be allowed a maximum of 5 minutes of extra time if they require it), and that they should alert the researcher when they are finished. 

The general order of events during the experimental session are as follows:

- Introduction to the task.
- Participant re-familiarises themselves with how to build the catapult.
- Once participant is ready, they are introduced to their first pupil, via vignette.
- The participant is instructed on the video making process.
- The participant makes the video for the first pupil.
- The participant indicates they are finished.
- The Lego catapult is reset.
- The researcher introduces the participant to the second pupil, via vignette.
- The participant is reminded of the video making process.
- The participant makes the video for the second pupil.
- The participant indicates they are finished.
- The participant gives feedback and the researcher delivers the incentive.

A full experiment script is available as an attachment to this question.

Teaching approaches will be compared across both videos (on a number of variables which will be described later), between the ASD and typically developing groups.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Adolescent children (11 to 15 year olds), who will act as "teachers" in the experiment, will be recruited via a variety of bodies (e.g. schools, council services, local clubs and organisations etc.). To recruit children with diagnoses of ASD, special education need coordinators will be approached in various schools in the south-west of England. When recruiting via schools, the parents/carers of prospective participants will be approached by a representative of the school to seek verbal permission for the researcher to get in touch with them, or to discuss their child's participation on the parent's behalf.

When the researcher is alerted to a prospective participant, they will discuss the suitability of the child for participation, with the appropriate adult (i.e. school representative or parent/carer). This conversation will involve checking the child's age, diagnoses, and whether they are performing at age-related targets for their verbal skills. If the child appears suitable for participation, then written consent will be sought from the parent and a date booked in for data collection to occur. As detailed in the design plan, at this point participants will undergo a more formal screening for general cognition. Any participants not meeting these criteria will be excluded from the analysis.

Participating children will be rewarded for their participation in the form of a Lego mini-figure (approximately worth £1.50 each). Parents of participating children will not be materially incentivised.

Recruitment will occur from the present (March 2020) until an appropriate sample size has been recruited. This is anticipated to be completed before the end of this academic year (July 2020).

Where all participants are either in the ASD or TD group, and all participants complete both pupil age conditions.

registration_responses.q17.question:
A number of variables will be measured in the screening and experimental phases of the study. The screening tools and the measurements drawn from these are detailed in the design plan. Here I will list the measures that will be recorded from the screening tools.

•	Participant Age
•	SCQ - Lifetime score.
•	WASI - Full Scale IQ (2 item)
•	WASI - Block Design Scaled Score
•	WASI - Vocabulary Scaled Score
•	ToM Triangles Animation - Accuracy Total Score
•	ToM Triangles Animation - Mentalisation Total Score

A new coding scheme based on available research has been devised to isolate components of teaching behaviours. These cover two modalities, verbal and audible.
•	Verbal = How language is used to convey instruction.
•	Acoustic = Properties of sound in the language used.

Verbal - Transcripts of the videos will be coded to identify each instructive step conveyed by the teacher. Each of these steps will be assigned two qualities: whether they are pupil-specific or generic; and whether the instruction is process focused or product focused. 

Specific vs generic was used as a contrast in Ashley and Tomasello (1998), in their comparison of 2.5, 3 and 3.5 year olds on a co-operative teaching task. In this experiment, a number of instructional qualities were considered however of key significance was the emergence of specific directive instructions in the older 3.5 year old group. 

Process vs product is a construct which distinguishes imitation from emulation. One of the major theories of cumulative cultural evolution posits that humans are process focused when they teach, we pass on the steps involved in teaching rather than conveying the final outcome. ToM is argued to be key to our ability to engage in process focused teaching.

I will treat both of these constructs as proportional variables, i.e. the amount of specific/generalised and process/product will be expressed as a % of the total instructions. Therefore only two variables will be necessary to capture this distinction, one variable for the proportion of specific instruction and one variable for the proportion of process instruction.

Examples of how transcripts will be coded, will follow:
•	“So now you make the handle”
o	This example is pupil specific because it directly addresses the pupil.
o	It is also product focused because it only describes the end state, not the process.
•	“The tower goes here, on the base of the catapult”
o	This example is generic, it does not directly address the pupil.
o	It is also a process focused instruction, because it describes how to perform the task.

Due to the nature of creating an instructional video teachers may use visual gestures to supplement their instruction giving. Coding will account for any visual aids used in the instruction giving process. Unless the teacher clearly demonstrates the process to the camera, the instruction will only be coded as product focused. For example:
•	“To make the head of the catapult, you put it together like this [Head is shown to screen]”
o	This would be pupil specific.
o	This would be process focused. Although the process is not described verbally, it is conveyed visually.

Additionally, we will capture how much instruction is given to different pupils through examination of the transcripts. Although we have not yet seen any teaching research explore this, it seems intuitively worth exploring. This will be captured in two ways:
•	Instructional count (i.e. the number of verbal instructions given to each pupil).
•	Words-per-minute (i.e. how many words are used from the time between the start of talking to the finish).

Acoustic – IDS is characterised by a number of augmentations to speech. In this experiment I do not have the means to measure all of these, however a number of bodies of work point to some augmentations which may be possible to be isolated. 

One of these is fundamental frequency (F0), the base pitch of our voice which is modulated to higher frequency bands when speaking to infants. In order to isolate and examine F0 differences across groups and pupil types, the researcher will follow the data scoring approach outlined in Braarud & Stormark (2008). In this study, the researchers cleaned the audio of background noise, then isolated each word or sound uttered by their participants as a ‘vocal unit’. Each of these vocal units was then subjected to pitch extraction to give an F0 for each 3.6ms of voice production. Mean F0 will be taken across vocal units produced for each participant and each video made.

Additionally we will investigate pause and utterance durations, in line with research from Fernald & Simon (1984). In this study, utterances were defined as any section of speech bounded by pauses of longer than 300ms. Pitch extraction, pause and utterance analysis will be performed in PRAAT.

Summary:
To summarise I have SEVEN dependent variables, which I will compare across groups and pupil types. These are: proportion of specific instructions, (relative to generic instructions), proportion of process instructions (relative to product instructions), counts of numbers of instructions given, words-per-minute, fundamental frequency (F0), mean pause duration and mean utterance duration.
registration_responses.q18.question: A principal components analysis will be conducted on the nine dependent measures. The exact method is described in the analysis plan section.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Prior to analysis of the data, groups will be compared to ensure they meet certain assumptions for the rationale. Groups will be contrasted on measures of motor-coordination (i.e. WASI block design), verbal skills (i.e. WASI vocabulary), general cognitive ability (i.e. predicted full scale IQ as compiled by a composite of block design and vocabulary performance) and theory of mind (i.e. triangles animation task). A one way ANOVA will be run on these measures, with group being a fixed factor. The control and ASD group will be assumed to match on motor co-ordination, verbal skills and general cognitive ability, but not match on the measure of theory of mind. If the one way ANOVA supports these assumptions, then I will proceed with the full analysis of the teaching data.

I will analyse the teaching data using a generalised linear mixed model (GLMM), specifying participant group and pupil type as fixed effects. Teacher identity will be fitted as a random effect to account for repeated measures. The outcome measures that are used in the model will depend on the outcome of an initial principal components analysis (PCA).

Two PCAs will be run; one for the verbal measures and one for the acoustic measures. If the PCA outcome gives components with Eigenvalues greater than 1, that are correlated, the GLMM will be run on the components to assess for significance. This means that a minimum of two GLMMs will be run, with the potential for further GLMMs if a PCA returns more than one component eigenvalue greater than 1.

If the PCA does not return components with Eigenvalues greater than 1 and correlated, then two separate GLMMs (for verbal and acoustic measures) will be run on the constituent dependent measures.

All the response variables are continuous. Standard residual checks will be administered to ensure that model assumptions are met for each analysis. If the distribution of the data is not Gaussian then a link function will be used to ensure that this is accounted for.

q1.value: How the Dark Tetrad Associates With Trolling Behavior

q2.value: Charles, Alyssa LeBlue , Lucy Chancellor, Alexis Lang, Barbara Flandez

q3.value:
Online trolling is deceptive and or destructive behavior shown through social settings on the internet. There is little empirical study done on trolling, but there is research on Dark Tetrad Personality traits (Machiavellianism, Narcissism, Sadism, Psychopathy) that suggest that those traits can be predictive of trolling. We will conduct two replication studies on the association of Dark Tetrad Personality traits as predictors of internet trolling that was initially done by Erin E. Buckels, Paul D. Trapnell, Delroy L. Paulhus (Buckels et. al 2014).
Study 1 will be focused on predicting trolling enjoyment, while study 2 will assess the enjoyment of commenting activity.

q4.value: Dark Tetrad Personality traits will be positively associated predictive effect with trolling enjoyment rates and the enjoyment of commenting activity. We hypothesize that the Dark Tetrad Personality Traits will show to be significant predictors of internet trolling.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
In Study 1, researchers recruited participants to complete online survey questions. The first set of measures (Short Sadistic Impulse Scale) contained ten items to asses the dispositional tendency to enjoy hurting others, which were rated on five-point scales (1= strongly disagree, 5=strongly agree). The second set of measures (Varieties of Sadistic Tendencies scale) included six items to assess direct sadism and seven items to assess vicarious sadism, which were rated on seven-point scales (1= not at all, 7=very much). Scores were standardized and summed to create a direct sadism composite score. A 27-item Short Dark Triad scale was used  to assess narcissism, Machiavellianism, and subclinical psychopathy (Buckels et al. 2014).

In Study 2, a 27-item Short Dark Triad scale assessed narcissism, Machiavellianism, and subclinical psychopathy. An 18-item Comprehensive Assessment of Sadistic Tendencies (CAST) assessed sadistic personalit, more specifically direct physical sadism, direct verbal sadism, and vicarious sadism. The items were rated on 5-point scales (1=strongly disagree, 5=strongly agree) (Buckels et al. 2014).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
In relation to Study 1, 418 participants will be recruited from Amazon's Mechanical Turk website. The sample will be restricted to respondents from the United States. The participants will recieve $0.50 in compensation for their time.
In relation to Study 2, a larger and more diverse sample will be used to apply enough statistical power to test hypothesis about the Dark Tetrad. Two large samples were collected online. The first sample will be composed of 188 Canadian psychology students. They will complete questionnaires for extra course credit. The second sample will be composed of 609 US residents who will be recruited on Amazon's Mechanical Turk website. They will receive $0.50 in compensation for their time. All participants in both studies will be administered surveys (Buckels et al.2014).

q15.value: All participants will answer all components of the surveys one time.

question.value:
There are six items measured in Study 1. First, the Short Sadistic Impulse Scale measures the variable of the tendency to enjoy hurting others. We will measure this by asking participants "Hurting people is exciting" (on a scale of 1-5, 1 being strongly disagree, 5 being strongly agree). Second, the Varieties of Sadistic Tendencies scale will measure direct sadism and vicarious sadism on a scale of 1-7, 1 being not at all, 7 being very much. Direct sadism will be measured with six items; one item will be "I enjoy hurting people." Vicarious sadism will be measured with seven items: one item will be "In video games, I like the realistic blood spurts." Lastly, the 27-item Short Dark Triad scale measures narcissism, Machiavellianism, and subclinical psychopathy (on a scale of 1-5, 1 being strongly disagree, 5 being strongly agree. Narcissism will be assessed with statements similar to "I have been compared to famous people." Machiavellianism will be assessed with items similar to "It's not wise to tell your secrets." Lastly, subclinical psychopathy will be measured with items like "Packback needs to be quick and nasty." 

In Study 2, we will measure size items. First, the 27-item Short Dark Triad scale will measure narcissism, Machiavellianism, and subclinical psychopathy (on a scale of 1-5, 1 being strongly disagree, 5 being strongly agree). The 18-item Comprehensive Assessment of Sadistic Tendencies will measure sadism by assessing three distinct varieties of sadistic tendencies (on a scale of 1-5, 1 being strongly disagree, 5 being strongly agree). Direct physical sadism will be measured by five items, similar to "I enjoy physically hurting people." Direct verbal sadism will be assessed by six items, similar to "I enjoy making jokes at the expense of others." Vicarious sadism will be measured by assessing seven items, similar to "I enjoy playing the villain in games and torturing other characters."

Study 1:
The Dark Tetrad will show a significant effect of trolling activity preference through a multivariate analysis. Planned orthogonal contrasts will be indicators of the significant effect for all Dark Tetrad measures: direct sadism, vicarious sadism, psychopathy, narcissism, and Machiavellianism. 

Study 2: 
Unique contributions of the Dark Tetrad on trolling enjoyment will be examined with a multiple regression analysis with data from the subsample of commenters. Total sadism, Machiavellianism, narcissism, and psychopathy will be entered as trolling enjoyment predictors. Additionally, sadism, Machiavellianism, and psychopathy will be controlled to see the association between narcissism and trolling enjoyment. Internet use will be controlled, but it will not affect association patterns.

q3.value:
The focus of this online-questionnaire study is on the epistemological beliefs of researchers from the field of psychology and neighboring disciplines (e.g., sociology, cognitive science). 
Since 2011, a number of articles have been published on the present replication crisis or “crisis of confidence” (Pashler & Wagenmakers, 2012) in psychology. Whereas most of these articles focused on “open science” practices (e.g., Munafo et al., 2017) and large-scale replication attempts (e.g., Open Science Collaboration, 2015), another group of papers addressed epistemological issues that may be related to the crisis (e.g., Earp & Trafimov, 2015; Fils, 2019; (Holtz & Monnerjahn, 2017; Holtz, in press).
The goal of the present study is to analyze 1) researchers’ epistemological beliefs and 2) their knowledge about different epistemological schools of thought. The newly developed epistemological beliefs questionnaire is intended to capture actual controversies in the field of epistemology instead of, for example, lay conceptions regarding epistemology (e.g., Bromme, Kiehnhus, & Stahl, 2008). The also newly developed epistemological knowledge test is meant to capture common misconceptions regarding different epistemological schools of thought as well as general knowledge in the field of epistemology.
The questionnaire will be disseminated via Facebook groups that focus on methods and practices in the field of psychology and via mailing lists. Participation is completely voluntary. No personally identifiable information is captured unless participants voluntarily offer personal or contact information in the comment fields. Entries into the comment field wille be stored seperate from the other responses.
References:

Bromme, R., Kienhues, D., & Stahl, E. (2008). Knowledge and epistemological beliefs: An intimate but complicate relationship. In M. S. Khine (ed.): Knowing, knowledge and beliefs (pp. 423-441). Springer, Dordrecht.
Earp, B. D., & Trafimow, D. (2015). Replication, falsification, and the crisis of confidence in social psychology. Frontiers in Psychology, 6: 621.
Flis, I. (2019). Psychologists psychologizing scientific psychology: An epistemological reading of the replication crisis. Theory & Psychology, 29(2), 158-181.
Holtz, P., & Monnerjahn, P. (2017). Falsificationism is not just ‘potential’ falsifiability, but requires ‘actual’ falsification: Social psychology, critical rationalism, and progress in science. Journal for the Theory of Social Behaviour, 47(3), 348-362.
Holtz, P. (in press). Asking Platt’s “two questions” with a view to social priming research: Are there any reasons to expect a different outcome, and what happens if we don’t find what we were looking for? Metapsychology.
Munafò, M. R., Nosek, B. A., Bishop, D. V., Button, K. S., Chambers, C. D., Du Sert, N. P., ... & Ioannidis, J. P. (2017). A manifesto for reproducible science. Nature human behaviour, 1(1), 1-9.
Pashler, H., & Wagenmakers, E. J. (2012). Editors’introduction to the special section on replicability in psychological science a crisis of confidence?. Perspectives on Psychological Science, 7(6), 528-530.
Open Science Collaboration. (2015). Estimating the reproducibility of psychological science. Science, 349(6251), aac4716.

q4.value:
H1: I expect that the "reformers´" (or open science endorsers´) epistemological beliefs do not differ much from those of "old school" psychologists who do not believe that there is a crisis in the field of psychology.

H2a: I believe that most participants (> 50%) will endorse postivist/inductivist epistemological beliefs over, e.g., critical rationalist or constructivist ones.
H2b: Psychologists who think of themselves as qualitative researchers will endorse mostly constructivist views.  

H3: I expect that there are several common misconceptions with regard to epistemological knowledge:
H3a: Many participants (> 50%) will think that  they know more about epistemology than they actually do (estimated no. of correct answers is higher than the actual no.)
H3b: Many participants (> 50%) misunderstand critical rationalism in that they believe that Popper's approach cannot be applied to statistically formulated hypotheses.
H3c: Many participants (> 50%) misunderstand critical rationalism in that they believe that Popper wanted social scientists to adopt the methods of the natural sciences (e.g., experiments). 
H3d: Many participants (> 50%)  misunderstand Kuhn's philosophy in that they believe that paradigm shifts lead to a growth of knowledge.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The online-questionnaire was created with the Qualtrics software. It comprises of
- socio-demographic questions
- questions on the researchers's scientific activities (papers, teaching, ...)
- their stance towards the current crisis and open science practices
- their epistemological beliefs (30 items)
- their knowledge about Popper's philosophy (10 items)
- their knowledge about Kuhn's philosophy (10 items)
- their knowledge about the logical positivists (10 items)
- their identification with their profession.

question.value: Below you find the complete questionnaire (version from March 10 2020)

I will attempt to identify a factor structure among the epistemological beliefs items in an explorative way. They are meant to capture positivist/inductivist beliefs, critical rationalist beliefs, Kuhn's beliefs, constructivist beliefs, "new experimentalist" beliefs, and different conceptualizations of truth. 
Knowledge test items will be aggregated by computing the sume of correctly answered items.

The analyis will mostly use descriptive statistics (frequencies). 
Exploratory factor analysis techniques and maybe cluster analytic techniques (or latent class analysis) will be used to identify patterns whithin the epistemological beliefs items.

Munafò, M. R., Nosek, B. A., Bishop, D. V., Button, K. S., Chambers, C. D., Du Sert, N. P., ... & Ioannidis, J. P. (2017). A manifesto for reproducible science. Nature human behaviour, 1(1), 1-9.
Pashler, H., & Wagenmakers, E. J. (2012). Editors’introduction to the special section on replicability in psychological science a crisis of confidence?. Perspectives on Psychological Science, 7(6), 528-530.
Open Science Collaboration. (2015). Estimating the reproducibility of psychological science. Science, 349(6251), aac4716.
registration_responses.q4:
H1: I expect that the "reformers´" (or open science endorsers´) epistemological beliefs do not differ much from those of "old school" psychologists who do not believe that there is a crisis in the field of psychology.

H2a: I believe that most participants (> 50%) will endorse postivist/inductivist epistemological beliefs over, e.g., critical rationalist or constructivist ones.
H2b: Psychologists who think of themselves as qualitative researchers will endorse mostly constructivist views.  

H3: I expect that there are several common misconceptions with regard to epistemological knowledge:
H3a: Many participants (> 50%) will think that  they know more about epistemology than they actually do (estimated no. of correct answers is higher than the actual no.)
H3b: Many participants (> 50%) misunderstand critical rationalism in that they believe that Popper's approach cannot be applied to statistically formulated hypotheses.
H3c: Many participants (> 50%) misunderstand critical rationalism in that they believe that Popper wanted social scientists to adopt the methods of the natural sciences (e.g., experiments). 
H3d: Many participants (> 50%)  misunderstand Kuhn's philosophy in that they believe that paradigm shifts lead to a growth of knowledge.

registration_responses.q8.question:
The online-questionnaire was created with the Qualtrics software. It comprises of
- socio-demographic questions
- questions on the researchers's scientific activities (papers, teaching, ...)
- their stance towards the current crisis and open science practices
- their epistemological beliefs (30 items)
- their knowledge about Popper's philosophy (10 items)
- their knowledge about Kuhn's philosophy (10 items)
- their knowledge about the logical positivists (10 items)
- their identification with their profession.
registration_responses.q12.question:
The questionnaire will be disseminated mainly via Facebook groups that focus on methods and practices in the field of psychology and via mailing lists. Participation is completely voluntary. No personally identifiable information is captured unless participants voluntarily offer personal or contact information in the comment fields. Entries into the comment field wille be stored seperate from the other responses.
Participants will receive a brief invitation and a link to the online-questionnaire at the Qualtrics platform.
There are no payments; participation is completely voluntary.
Filling in the questionnaire will take approximately 30-40 minutes.
registration_responses.q17.question: Below you find the complete questionnaire (version from March 10 2020)
registration_responses.q18.question:
I will attempt to identify a factor structure among the epistemological beliefs items in an explorative way. They are meant to capture positivist/inductivist beliefs, critical rationalist beliefs, Kuhn's beliefs, constructivist beliefs, "new experimentalist" beliefs, and different conceptualizations of truth. 
Knowledge test items will be aggregated by computing the sume of correctly answered items.
registration_responses.q19.question:
The analyis will mostly use descriptive statistics (frequencies). 
Exploratory factor analysis techniques and maybe cluster analytic techniques (or latent class analysis) will be used to identify patterns whithin the epistemological beliefs items.

attributes.title: Implicit-explicit motive congruence/incongruence and mindfulness
attributes.description: The study aims at investigating if highly mindful individuals have a higher implicit-explicit motive congrunce.

q1.value: Does mindfulness lead to more congruent implicit and explicit motives?

q3.value:
This study aims at investigating the relationship between mindfulness and implicit-explicit motives congruence. Specifically, the previous research indicated that a brief mindfulness excercise may promote the implicit-explicit affiliation motive congruence (Strick & Papies, 2017). However, the same researchers could not find similar results for the effect of the brief intervention on the congruence between implicit-explicit power motives. These findings are somewhat surprising as the main idea behind mindfulness excercises is that people who are mindful are more aware of their implicit motives and thus, could set explicit goals (explicit motives) more in line with these implicit motives. It is important to note that the motive domain (be it affiliation, achievement or power) should not make a difference in showing such results. 

Based on these, this study has several aims. The first aim (and thus the first study) is to demonstrate if mindfulness as a trait moderate the relationship between implicit and explicit motives (affiliation, achievement and power). That is, we aimed at testing the idea that people who are high on mindfulness as a trait are higher on implicit-explicit motive congruence than those who are low on mindfulness. 

Furthermore, with a second study, we want to show if people who have exercised meditation have higher motive congruence than those who have not exercised meditation.

q4.value:
1. People who are high on mindfulness as a trait have more implicit-explicit motive congruence (for affiliation, achievement and power motives). 

2. Those people who have been exercising meditation would have higher implicit-explicit motive congruence (affiliation, achievement and power motives) than those people who have not exercised meditation. 

     2a. We expect a  non-linear relationship of the effects of duration of meditation exercised and the implicit-explicit motive congruence.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
As this project will include two studies, there are two study designs to mention. 

1. The first study's design is cross-sectional. We gather data via an online survey with various questionnaires and measures sent to paricipants. There is no randomization of participants to different groups nor manipulations. 

2. The second study's design is a quasi-experimenal design. We aim at gathering data from individuals who have been excercising meditation regularly and from individuals who have not exercised meditation even once. Thus, one could say the non-meditator group is control and the meditator group is experimental group. However, there is no manipulation or randomization to any of these groups.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
1. For the first study, the data is going to be collected with an online survey, sent to a pool of participants who register to participate in studies towards a bonus grade on their final exam grades.  The participants will not get any other compensations except for the bonus grade. The online survey will be in German and thus, those people who have at least B2 German language knowledge will be eligible to be the participants. The data collection for this study will be done in the next 15 days (starting from today 14.03.2020). 

2. The second study will be part of a master thesis. The data collection will be through contacting meditation centers around Munich and in other countries, like Turkey, and asking them if the people exercising meditation at those centers want to participate in the study. As a compensation, participants will have the opportunity to earn among three 15€s by participating in the lottery at the end of the study. Further, for the second group (non-meditator group), the link to an online survey will be posted on social media and on platforms for data collection. The participants in this group will also be given the opportunity to earn among hree 15€ by participation in the lottery at the end of the study. In short, there will be two target groups for data collection. One meditating and the other non-meditation. The both of the groups will be given links to online questionnaires and will be asked to answer the questionnaires and measures in the online study. Further, individuals in each group will be given the chance to earn among three 15€ by a lottery at the end of the study, as a compensation.

q13.value:
1. The first study will include approximately 300-400 individuals and all of the participants will be included in the study unless they do not fill out the questionnaires completely or have a lower German language level than B2. 

2. The second study will include two samples, one from people who have been exercising meditation and the other from those who have not exercised meditation. There will be at least 70 participants in each sample.

q14.value:
1. For the first study, reling on the previous studies (Job & Brandstätter, 2009; Strick & Papies, 2017) a sample size of 120 participants was required to get a medium effect size of f² = .15 with a 95% power (Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, & Lang, 2009). However, as we did not want to give bonus credits to some students and not give to others (fairness principle), we decided to include all of the participants filling ou our questionnaire, which we expect a number between 300 and 400. 

2. As for the second study, we again relied on the previous research (Job & Brandstätter, 2009; Strick & Papies, 2017). Assumng that our meditation group will be similar in terms of effect size, a sample of 19 would be required to observe the similar effects. However, Strick and Papies reported a partial eta-squared of 0.06 with an interaction between implicit motive and condition (experimental and control group). Using this effect size and a 95% power, we decided to have a total sample of 120, thus we expect for each group (meditators and non-meditators) to have at least 60 participants.

question.value:
In the first study, we will measure the following variables. 

1. Implicit motives (affiliation, achievement and power): these variables will be measured by The Motive Self-Categorization Test (Runge & Lang, 2019). This test combines the traditional motive tests (i.e., showing participants a set of ambigious pictures and asking participants to write stories for each participant. Then, a number of trained content-coders code the content of each specific test in accordance with their content of affiliation, achievement and power) and traditional self-report measures. It includes two parts. In the first part, participants are showed 15 ambigious pictures tapping into different every-day life events and are asked select a main character of the pictures and then write answer three open-ended questions regarding this person. In the second part of the study, participants are shown the same set of pictures again as well as a list of picture-specific statements. Participants have the opportunity to see the stories they wrote for each picture in the first part of the study and and indicate the statement that describes the stories they wrote for each specific picture the best. 

2. Explicit motives. Explicit motives are measured with Personality Research Form (Jackson, 1984). As the theoretical conception of the subscales affiliation, achievement and dominance fits very well to the conceptualization of explicit affiliation, achievement and power motives, motive research has long been using this scale to measure explicit motives. Thus, we also used this scale. Each subscale (affiliation, achievement and power) includes 16 items and participants are asked to respond to each item on a True/False scale. The sample item for affiliaton, achievement and power are "I spend a lot of time visiting my friends.", "My goal is to do at least a little bit more than anyone else has done before.", and "I try to control others rather than permit them to control me." respectively. 

3. Goal-Selection Task: Job and Bandstätter (2009) developed and used this task to measure explicit affiliation, achievement and power goals at the workplace. Individuals are presented with a scenario and are asked to imagine themselves in the scenario (that they have finsihed their studies and they have found a job in a short time after graduation. Now, they are asked to think about the goals they want to achieve in their new job.). After reading the scenario, participants are presented 15 goals (for each motive domain 5 goals) and are asked if they think they will strive for these goals in their new position.

4. Mindfulness: Mindfulness is measured with Mindful Attention Awareness Scale (MAAS; Brown & Ryan, 2003). The questionnaire measures mindfulness as a trait and includes 15 items measured on 6-point Likert type scale. An exmple item is "I could be experiencing some emotion and not be conscious of it until some time later.". 

5. Neuroticism: Neuroticism is measured wih the NEO-FFI (Costa & McCrae, 1992). Neuroticims subscale of the questionnaire includes 12 items and the respondents are asked to indicate the extent to which they agree or disagree with each item on a 5-point Likert Scale. 

6. Demographics 

For the second study, the variables measured in the first study will be measured in each group (meditating and non-meditating group). Further, in the meditating group participants will be asked how long and how often they exercise meditation.
The measures will be combined into an index via taking their means.

In all of the studies, I am planning to run descriptive statistics, like mean and standard deviation as well as I am planning to run correlation analyses to check the correlation among the variables. For each study, I plan to perform the following statistical analyses:

For study 1, I am planning to run a moderation analysis with R or SPSS. In the moderation analysis, dependent variable will be explicit motives, implicit motives will be dependent variable and mindfulness will be moderator. Further, I plan to run simple slope analyses with one standard deviation above and below the mean (for the moderator). Further, as the previous research (Job & Brandstätter, 2009) approaches the explicit motive goals (measured with Goal Selection Task), I will specifically focus on the correlation between explicit motives and explicit motive goals to see if one actually can accept the both as one. 

For the second study, I am planning to run a multilevel model with two groups (meditating and non-meditating) included in group level (level 2) and the moderator analysis specified above included in the participant level (level 1). Further, as in the first study, I plan to run simple-slope analyses for each group separately.

q20.value: In case there is an inflated VIF, I plan to center the variables to bring the VIF in state that do not affect the results as much.

q21.value: P-values will be used (p < .05; .01; .001). As for the multilevel modeling, different models will be compared (random-intercept only, random-slope only and random-intercept random slope models), thus BIC and AIC will be used. The smaller these criteria, the more improved the model is.

q22.value: I am not planning to exclude any data from my analyses if they are not missing or have extremely unlikely values (for example if there is no variance in one's answers on a scale).

q23.value: Missing data will be completely excluded from the analyses.
