q1.value: Can we capture cognitive aspects of catastrophising using a computerised task?

q2.value: Alexandra C Pike, Agatha Anet, Oliver J Robinson

q3.value: Catastrophising is often defined as imagining or predicting the worst possible outcome. It is akin to the cognitive distortion of ‘magnification’ proposed by Beck in his work on depression, which entails underestimating one’s own abilities and over-estimating the magnitude and severity of negative events (Beck, 1963). Higher levels of catastrophising are seen in those who describe themselves as worriers (Davey et al. 2007, Garnefski et al. 2006) and those with high levels of anxiety (Garnefski and Kraaij, 2018; Dickson, 2006). Those with a diagnosis of depression also show increased catastrophising (Garnefski and Kraaij, 2018, Garnefski et al. 2006). Catastrophising is also associated with an increase in negative mood and decrease in positive mood (Davey and Wells, 2006). Recently, our research group has developed a self-report questionnaire to measure catastrophising, higher scores on which are found in those with self-reported diagnoses of anxiety or depression (Pike, Serfaty and Robinson, under review). However, the cognitive processes behind catastrophising itself are still unknown. The objective of this study is therefore to develop/modify cognitive tasks in order to better understand the cognitive mechanisms underlying catastrophising.

q4.value:
H1: The more participants catastrophise, the less likely they are to take risks.
H2: The more participants catastrophise, the more they will avoid negative outcomes.
H3: The more participants catastrophise, the more they will tend to predict worse outcomes in the future.
H4: The more participants catastrophise, the worse they will evaluate their performance to be.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study is observational, and between-subjects: key task metrics will be regressed with scores on a catastrophising questionnaire. The study will consist of three tasks that will be completed online and four brief questionnaires to assess catastrophising, anxiety, depression and worry, respectively: the Catastrophising Questionnaire, the Generalised Anxiety Disorder Assessment (GAD-7), the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9) and the Penn State Worry Questionnaire (PSWQ). For ethical reasons, we remove the question asking about suicidal thoughts and behaviours from the PHQ-9 when testing online; thus, this questionnaire will consist of the remaining eight items.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants shall be recruited using Prolific (https://app.prolific.co/) and will give consent within Gorilla and will be able to withdraw from the experiment at any time. They shall be reimbursed for their time at the rate of £7.50/hour. Contact details of the experimenters will be listed in case participants wish to ask for further information before participating. 

Inclusion criteria
•	Aged between 18-40 years
•	English as first language or fluency in English
Exclusion criteria
•	History of mild cognitive impairment or dementia
•	Impaired or uncorrected vision

q13.value: 63 participants with complete data (30 in first instance to check analysis pipeline)

q14.value: A sample size of 63 participants is required to achieve 95% power (at alpha = 0.05) to detect effect sizes of over d=0.4 in a Pearson’s correlation test.

question.value:
Questionnaires: GAD-7, PHQ-9 (excluding suicide question), PSWQ, Catastrophising Questionnaire
BART task: Number of balloon pumps per trial, number of 'burst' balloons, number of selections of 'collect points'
Maths task: Self-rating of ability to answer maths questions, self-rating of performance, rating of question difficulty (all on visual analog scales), question answers (numeric)
Gambling task: Predicted score at the end of the task for each block and estimation of points for current block

1. Mean number of pumps will be calculated separately for BART block 1 and BART block 2
2. Difference in number of pumps before and after the 3rd and 7th balloon of BART block 2 will be calculated using subtraction
3. Gamma (risk-taking parameter) will be calculated for each BART block separately using the hBayesDM model here: https://rdrr.io/cran/hBayesDM/man/bart_par4.html and obtained using Stan and R.
4. Total correct/incorrect questions will be calculated by summing in the Maths task. All visual analog scale responses will be quantised using the inbuilt Gorilla system for visual analog scales.

The data will be analysed using JASP and/or R software, and analysis will take the form of correlation and multiple regression analysis. To test hypothesis 1: “The more participants catastrophise, the less likely they are to take risks” we will use a Spearman’s rank test to understand the relationship between the number of pumps and the score in the catastrophising questionnaire. Additionally, we will use sampling in Stan with a hBayesDM model for the BART task (https://rdrr.io/cran/hBayesDM/man/bart_par4.html) and perform a Pearson’s correlation between the resulting gamma parameter (which indexes risk-taking) and Catastrophising Scores, in both blocks 1 and 2. For hypothesis 2: “The more participants catastrophise, the more they will avoid negative outcomes” we will examine the relationship between the score in the catastrophising questionnaire and the delta between the number of pumps before and after balloons with the lowest pumps required to burst (2 and 3 pumps) using correlation analysis using a Spearman’s correlation. Hypothesis 3: “The more participants catastrophise, the more they will tend to predict worse outcomes in the future.” will be examined by calculating the difference between points earned and points predicted, this difference will be correlated using a Spearman’s correlation with the score in the catastrophising questionnaire. Lastly, to test hypothesis 4: “The more participants catastrophise the more they have a tendency to evaluate their performance as worse than it actually is” we will use multiple regression to analyse the relationship between scores in the catastrophising questionnaires with the self-rated score about their level of maths, adding as covariates the number of right answers, and the level of difficulty of the problems, and the self-rated score on their performance. We may also build exploratory models of the gambling task (hypothesis 3) and the mathematics task (hypothesis 4), but these are not the primary outcomes of this study. We may also include scores on the other questionnaire measures as covariates to test the specificity of any relationship between catastrophising and our outcome variables.

q21.value: We will use p values of 0.05 to make inferences. Correlations will be one-tailed, as we expect a negative correlation in all the above hypotheses except hypothesis 2, in which we expect a positive relationship between delta and catastrophising. We will not correct for multiple comparisons as we are not testing the same hypothesis repeatedly, and this work is exploratory. We plan to follow this work up with out-of-sample predictions.

q22.value: Participants will be manually inspected and may be excluded if they have selected the same response throughout a questionnaire (e.g. only 'sometimes' or only 'always'). Participants will be excluded if they do not enter numbers in the maths task or gambling tasks. registration_responses.q1: Can we capture cognitive aspects of catastrophising using a computerised task?
registration_responses.q2: Alexandra C Pike, Agatha Anet, Oliver J Robinson
registration_responses.q3: Catastrophising is often defined as imagining or predicting the worst possible outcome. It is akin to the cognitive distortion of ‘magnification’ proposed by Beck in his work on depression, which entails underestimating one’s own abilities and over-estimating the magnitude and severity of negative events (Beck, 1963). Higher levels of catastrophising are seen in those who describe themselves as worriers (Davey et al. 2007, Garnefski et al. 2006) and those with high levels of anxiety (Garnefski and Kraaij, 2018; Dickson, 2006). Those with a diagnosis of depression also show increased catastrophising (Garnefski and Kraaij, 2018, Garnefski et al. 2006). Catastrophising is also associated with an increase in negative mood and decrease in positive mood (Davey and Wells, 2006). Recently, our research group has developed a self-report questionnaire to measure catastrophising, higher scores on which are found in those with self-reported diagnoses of anxiety or depression (Pike, Serfaty and Robinson, under review). However, the cognitive processes behind catastrophising itself are still unknown. The objective of this study is therefore to develop/modify cognitive tasks in order to better understand the cognitive mechanisms underlying catastrophising.
registration_responses.q4:
H1: The more participants catastrophise, the less likely they are to take risks.
H2: The more participants catastrophise, the more they will avoid negative outcomes.
H3: The more participants catastrophise, the more they will tend to predict worse outcomes in the future.
H4: The more participants catastrophise, the worse they will evaluate their performance to be.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q13: 63 participants with complete data (30 in first instance to check analysis pipeline)
registration_responses.q14: A sample size of 63 participants is required to achieve 95% power (at alpha = 0.05) to detect effect sizes of over d=0.4 in a Pearson’s correlation test.
registration_responses.q21: We will use p values of 0.05 to make inferences. Correlations will be one-tailed, as we expect a negative correlation in all the above hypotheses except hypothesis 2, in which we expect a positive relationship between delta and catastrophising. We will not correct for multiple comparisons as we are not testing the same hypothesis repeatedly, and this work is exploratory. We plan to follow this work up with out-of-sample predictions.

registration_responses.q8.question: This study is observational, and between-subjects: key task metrics will be regressed with scores on a catastrophising questionnaire. The study will consist of three tasks that will be completed online and four brief questionnaires to assess catastrophising, anxiety, depression and worry, respectively: the Catastrophising Questionnaire, the Generalised Anxiety Disorder Assessment (GAD-7), the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9) and the Penn State Worry Questionnaire (PSWQ). For ethical reasons, we remove the question asking about suicidal thoughts and behaviours from the PHQ-9 when testing online; thus, this questionnaire will consist of the remaining eight items.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants shall be recruited using Prolific (https://app.prolific.co/) and will give consent within Gorilla and will be able to withdraw from the experiment at any time. They shall be reimbursed for their time at the rate of £7.50/hour. Contact details of the experimenters will be listed in case participants wish to ask for further information before participating. 

Inclusion criteria
•	Aged between 18-40 years
•	English as first language or fluency in English
Exclusion criteria
•	History of mild cognitive impairment or dementia
•	Impaired or uncorrected vision
registration_responses.q17.question:
Questionnaires: GAD-7, PHQ-9 (excluding suicide question), PSWQ, Catastrophising Questionnaire
BART task: Number of balloon pumps per trial, number of 'burst' balloons, number of selections of 'collect points'
Maths task: Self-rating of ability to answer maths questions, self-rating of performance, rating of question difficulty (all on visual analog scales), question answers (numeric)
Gambling task: Predicted score at the end of the task for each block and estimation of points for current block
registration_responses.q18.question:
1. Mean number of pumps will be calculated separately for BART block 1 and BART block 2
2. Difference in number of pumps before and after the 3rd and 7th balloon of BART block 2 will be calculated using subtraction
3. Gamma (risk-taking parameter) will be calculated for each BART block separately using the hBayesDM model here: https://rdrr.io/cran/hBayesDM/man/bart_par4.html and obtained using Stan and R.
4. Total correct/incorrect questions will be calculated by summing in the Maths task. All visual analog scale responses will be quantised using the inbuilt Gorilla system for visual analog scales.
registration_responses.q19.question: The data will be analysed using JASP and/or R software, and analysis will take the form of correlation and multiple regression analysis. To test hypothesis 1: “The more participants catastrophise, the less likely they are to take risks” we will use a Spearman’s rank test to understand the relationship between the number of pumps and the score in the catastrophising questionnaire. Additionally, we will use sampling in Stan with a hBayesDM model for the BART task (https://rdrr.io/cran/hBayesDM/man/bart_par4.html) and perform a Pearson’s correlation between the resulting gamma parameter (which indexes risk-taking) and Catastrophising Scores, in both blocks 1 and 2. For hypothesis 2: “The more participants catastrophise, the more they will avoid negative outcomes” we will examine the relationship between the score in the catastrophising questionnaire and the delta between the number of pumps before and after balloons with the lowest pumps required to burst (2 and 3 pumps) using correlation analysis using a Spearman’s correlation. Hypothesis 3: “The more participants catastrophise, the more they will tend to predict worse outcomes in the future.” will be examined by calculating the difference between points earned and points predicted, this difference will be correlated using a Spearman’s correlation with the score in the catastrophising questionnaire. Lastly, to test hypothesis 4: “The more participants catastrophise the more they have a tendency to evaluate their performance as worse than it actually is” we will use multiple regression to analyse the relationship between scores in the catastrophising questionnaires with the self-rated score about their level of maths, adding as covariates the number of right answers, and the level of difficulty of the problems, and the self-rated score on their performance. We may also build exploratory models of the gambling task (hypothesis 3) and the mathematics task (hypothesis 4), but these are not the primary outcomes of this study. We may also include scores on the other questionnaire measures as covariates to test the specificity of any relationship between catastrophising and our outcome variables.
